title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Corinthians chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Corinthians Chapter 3.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 3:1, how did Paul describe the Corinthians in relation to spiritual maturity?
questions.explanation: Paul said he could not speak to them as spiritual but as carnal, even as unto babes in Christ (1 Corinthians 3:1).

questions.question: What kind of food did Paul say he fed the Corinthians in 1 Corinthians 3:2?
questions.explanation: Paul said he fed them with milk and not with meat because they were not able to bear it (1 Corinthians 3:2).

questions.question: What were some of the issues among the Corinthians mentioned in 1 Corinthians 3:3?
questions.explanation: The verse states that there was envying, strife, and divisions among them, showing their carnality (1 Corinthians 3:3).

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 3:4, what did some Corinthians say that revealed their carnality?
questions.explanation: Some said, 'I am of Paul,' and others said, 'I am of Apollos,' showing division and carnality (1 Corinthians 3:4).

questions.question: Who are described as ministers by whom believers came to faith, according to 1 Corinthians 3:5?
questions.explanation: Paul and Apollos are called ministers by whom the Corinthians believed, as given by the Lord (1 Corinthians 3:5).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 3:6, what roles did Paul and Apollos play?
questions.explanation: Paul planted and Apollos watered, but God gave the increase (1 Corinthians 3:6).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 3:11, what is the only foundation that can be laid?
questions.explanation: No other foundation can be laid than that which is laid, which is Jesus Christ (1 Corinthians 3:11).

questions.question: What will the fire do to every man's work, as described in 1 Corinthians 3:13?
options: Try every man's work of what sort it is
questions.correctAnswer: Try every man's work of what sort it is
questions.explanation: The fire will try every man's work to reveal its quality (1 Corinthians 3:13).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 3:16, what are believers described as?
questions.explanation: Believers are described as the temple of God where the Spirit of God dwells (1 Corinthians 3:16).

questions.question: What will happen to anyone who defiles the temple of God, according to 1 Corinthians 3:17?
questions.explanation: If anyone defiles the temple of God, God will destroy him because the temple is holy (1 Corinthians 3:17).

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 3:7, Paul says that he who plants and he who waters are the most important.
questions.explanation: Paul says neither he who plants nor he who waters is anything, but God who gives the increase is the most important (1 Corinthians 3:7).

questions.question: True or False: 1 Corinthians 3:18 encourages believers to become fools in order to become wise.
questions.explanation: The verse advises that if anyone seems wise in this world, let him become a fool to become truly wise (1 Corinthians 3:18).

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 3:23, believers belong to Christ and Christ belongs to God.
questions.explanation: The verse states that believers are Christ's and Christ is God's (1 Corinthians 3:23).

questions.question: Complete this verse from 1 Corinthians 3:10: 'According to the grace of God which is given unto me, as a wise masterbuilder, I have laid the _______, and another buildeth thereon.'
questions.explanation: Paul says he laid the foundation according to the grace of God (1 Corinthians 3:10).

questions.question: Complete this verse from 1 Corinthians 3:12: 'Now if any man build upon this foundation gold, silver, precious stones, _______, hay, stubble;'
questions.explanation: The verse lists wood, hay, and stubble as materials built upon the foundation (1 Corinthians 3:12).

medium.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Corinthians Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with jealousy and division in their church. Based on 1 Corinthians 3, what biblical truth would you share about unity?
options: It is good to align strictly with one leader.
Paul and Apollos are competing leaders.
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 3:3-4 explains that envying, strife, and divisions are signs of carnality, and believers are urged to move beyond this immature behavior.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 3 teach us about relying on God in our work and service?
options: God is the one who gives growth and increase.
Only the founder of a ministry matters.
questions.correctAnswer: God is the one who gives growth and increase.
questions.explanation: Verses 6 and 7 state that while Paul planted and Apollos watered, it is God who gives the increase, emphasizing dependence on God’s power in all ministry.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 3, what is the foundation upon which Christians should build their lives?
questions.explanation: Verse 11 clearly states that no other foundation can be laid than that which is Jesus Christ, establishing Him as the essential base for Christian life.

questions.question: If a Christian’s work is tested by fire and remains, what will happen according to this chapter?
questions.explanation: Verse 14 explains that if any man’s work endures the testing by fire, he will receive a reward, teaching the value of faithful service.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to boast about their spiritual leader. What does 1 Corinthians 3 advise?
options: Boast only in Paul since he planted the church.
Boast in Apollos for your spiritual growth.
Do not glory in men because all things belong to you.
questions.correctAnswer: Do not glory in men because all things belong to you.
questions.explanation: Verses 21-22 teach that no one should boast in men since all things belong to the believers, emphasizing humility and unity in Christ.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 3 teach about the character of true wisdom?
options: Worldly wisdom is the highest form of wisdom.
True wisdom is becoming foolish by worldly standards to become wise in God’s sight.
questions.correctAnswer: True wisdom is becoming foolish by worldly standards to become wise in God’s sight.
questions.explanation: Verse 18 instructs believers to become fools in the eyes of the world to become truly wise, showing that godly wisdom differs from worldly wisdom.

questions.question: What warning does 1 Corinthians 3 give about defiling the temple of God?
options: God will forgive all offenses lightly.
God will destroy anyone who defiles His temple.
The temple is just a metaphor with no consequences.
Only the church leaders are responsible for the temple.
questions.correctAnswer: God will destroy anyone who defiles His temple.
questions.explanation: Verse 17 warns that God will destroy anyone who defiles His temple, emphasizing the holiness of the believer’s body as God’s dwelling.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 3, what roles did Paul and Apollos have in the church?
options: They were rivals competing for followers.
They were ministers who planted and watered the seed of faith.
They were the only spiritual leaders allowed.
They were apostles with equal authority.
questions.correctAnswer: They were ministers who planted and watered the seed of faith.
questions.explanation: Verses 5-6 describe Paul as the one who planted and Apollos as the one who watered, but God gave the increase, showing their cooperative ministry roles.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 3, believers are described as God's building and husbandry.
questions.explanation: Verse 9 refers to believers as God’s husbandry and building, illustrating their identity as God’s cared-for people and His spiritual construction.

questions.question: True or False: The wisdom of this world is highly regarded by God according to 1 Corinthians 3.
questions.explanation: Verse 19 states that the wisdom of this world is foolishness to God, showing that God values His own wisdom above worldly knowledge.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "Know ye not that ye are the ______ of God, and that the Spirit of God dwelleth in you?"
questions.explanation: Verse 16 teaches that believers are the temple of God and the Spirit dwells in them, emphasizing the sacredness of their lives.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 3 encourage believers to approach building their lives and ministries?
options: Build without concern for the foundation.
Build carefully on the foundation of Jesus Christ.
questions.correctAnswer: Build carefully on the foundation of Jesus Christ.
questions.explanation: Verse 10 instructs believers to take heed how they build upon the foundation laid, which is Jesus Christ, stressing careful and wise building of one’s life.

questions.question: A believer is concerned about their works being tested after death. What does 1 Corinthians 3 say about this testing?
options: Works are not tested after death.
Works will be revealed and tested by fire to determine their value.
All works will be burned without exception.
Only the works of pastors are tested.
questions.correctAnswer: Works will be revealed and tested by fire to determine their value.
questions.explanation: Verse 13 states that every man’s work will be revealed by fire, which will test its quality, teaching the reality of judgment for works.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 3, what is the relationship between those who plant and water in ministry?
options: They are one in purpose and will each receive a reward.
questions.correctAnswer: They are one in purpose and will each receive a reward.
questions.explanation: Verse 8 explains that the planter and waterer are one, and each will receive a reward according to their labor, highlighting unity in ministry.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 3 guide believers in humility when they think they are wise?
options: Trust in your own wisdom above all else.
Become a fool in this world’s eyes to become truly wise.
Boast about your knowledge to others.
questions.correctAnswer: Become a fool in this world’s eyes to become truly wise.
questions.explanation: Verse 18 advises believers not to deceive themselves but to become foolish by worldly standards in order to gain true wisdom from God.

hard.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Corinthians Chapter 3.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 3, Paul describes the believers as "babes in Christ" because:
options: They were still carnal and immature in their faith
They were leaders in the church
questions.correctAnswer: They were still carnal and immature in their faith
questions.explanation: Paul states in 1 Corinthians 3:1 that he could not speak to them as spiritual but as carnal, even as babes in Christ, indicating their immaturity.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 3, what metaphor does Paul use to describe the early stage of the Corinthian believers' spiritual nourishment?
questions.explanation: In 1 Corinthians 3:2, Paul says he fed them with milk, not meat, because they were not yet able to bear stronger spiritual teachings.

questions.question: What issue among the Corinthian believers does Paul highlight to show their carnality?
questions.explanation: Paul points out in 1 Corinthians 3:3 that envying, strife, and divisions indicate their carnality.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 3, Paul mentions two leaders to whom some Corinthians aligned themselves. Who are they?
questions.explanation: Verses 4 and 5 mention some saying 'I am of Paul' and others 'I am of Apollos,' emphasizing factions.

questions.question: What analogy does Paul use to describe his and Apollos' roles in the growth of the Corinthian church?
options: Paul planted, Apollos watered, but God gave the increase
Paul built the house, Apollos furnished it
Paul led the army, Apollos was the general
Paul sowed the seed, Apollos harvested the crop
questions.correctAnswer: Paul planted, Apollos watered, but God gave the increase
questions.explanation: Paul explains in 1 Corinthians 3:6 that he planted, Apollos watered, but God gave the growth.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 3, who ultimately is responsible for the growth and increase of the believers?
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states that neither the planter nor the waterer is anything, but God who gives the increase.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 3, Paul calls the believers 'God's building.' What Old Testament imagery does this evoke?
questions.explanation: Referring to believers as God's building (v. 9) alludes to the temple imagery like Solomon’s temple, a sacred place for God's presence.

questions.question: What foundation does Paul say no man can lay other than what is already laid in 1 Corinthians 3?
questions.explanation: Paul declares in 1 Corinthians 3:11 that no foundation can be laid other than Jesus Christ.

questions.question: Paul describes different materials used to build upon the foundation in 1 Corinthians 3. Which of the following is NOT mentioned?
questions.explanation: Verse 12 lists gold, silver, precious stones, wood, hay, and stubble, but iron is not mentioned.

questions.question: What does the 'fire' represent in Paul's analogy about testing each man's work in 1 Corinthians 3?
options: Judgment on the quality of each person's work
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment on the quality of each person's work
questions.explanation: Verse 13 explains that fire will reveal the quality of each man's work, symbolizing divine judgment.

questions.question: What is the outcome for those whose work is burned up, according to 1 Corinthians 3?
options: They suffer loss but are still saved, yet so as by fire
They are condemned and lost forever
They receive no reward but remain faithful
They are punished with temporal affliction
questions.correctAnswer: They suffer loss but are still saved, yet so as by fire
questions.explanation: Verse 15 describes that if a man's work is burned, he suffers loss but himself will be saved as through fire.

questions.question: Paul refers to the believers as the 'temple of God' where the Spirit dwells. Which Old Testament concept does this directly echo?
options: The indwelling of God in the tabernacle and temple
The creation of Adam as God's image
The giving of the Ten Commandments
questions.correctAnswer: The indwelling of God in the tabernacle and temple
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 3:16 alludes to the Old Testament idea where God’s presence dwelled in the tabernacle and temple, now within believers.

questions.question: What warning does Paul give about defiling the temple of God in 1 Corinthians 3?
questions.explanation: Verse 17 warns that if anyone defiles the temple of God, God will destroy him, emphasizing the holiness of believers as God's temple.

questions.question: Paul contrasts worldly wisdom with God’s wisdom in 1 Corinthians 3. Which Old Testament phrase does he quote to support this?
options: He taketh the wise in their own craftiness
The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom
Blessed is the man who walks not in the counsel of the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: He taketh the wise in their own craftiness
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 3:19 quotes this phrase from Job 5:13 to illustrate the folly of worldly wisdom compared to God's wisdom.

questions.question: Paul instructs the Corinthians to take no pride in men because 'all things are yours.' Which of the following is NOT included in the list of 'all things' from 1 Corinthians 3?
questions.explanation: Verses 21-22 list Paul, Apollos, Cephas, the world, life, death, things present, and things to come, but not 'the law.'

theological.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Corinthians Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 3, why did Paul say he could not speak to the Corinthians as spiritual but as carnal?
options: Because they were still envying and divided
Because they were mature in faith
questions.correctAnswer: Because they were still envying and divided
questions.explanation: Paul identifies their carnality due to envying, strife, and divisions among them (1 Corinthians 3:1-3). This is consistent with James 3:14-16 and Galatians 5:19-21 where such behaviors are signs of fleshly nature.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 3, what metaphor does Paul use to describe the spiritual nourishment he initially gave the Corinthians?
questions.explanation: Paul states he fed them with milk and not with meat because they were not able to bear stronger teaching (1 Corinthians 3:2). Hebrews 5:12-14 similarly contrasts milk and solid food as stages of spiritual growth.

questions.question: What does Paul say about the roles of Paul and Apollos in the work of God in 1 Corinthians 3?
options: Paul planted, Apollos watered, but God gave the increase
Apollos planted, Paul watered, and Paul gave the increase
Paul and Apollos both planted and watered equally
God planted and watered, and Paul and Apollos increased
questions.correctAnswer: Paul planted, Apollos watered, but God gave the increase
questions.explanation: Paul clarifies that though he planted and Apollos watered, it is God who gives the growth, emphasizing God's sovereignty (1 Corinthians 3:6-7). This aligns with John 3:27 and Psalm 127:1 which affirm God's ultimate role in growth and success.

questions.question: How does Paul describe the foundation upon which believers must build according to 1 Corinthians 3?
questions.explanation: Paul states that no other foundation can be laid than that which is Jesus Christ (1 Corinthians 3:11). This is consistent with Ephesians 2:20 and Isaiah 28:16, which identify Christ as the cornerstone of the church.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 3, what will happen to each man's work when it is tested by fire?
options: It will be revealed for its quality
It will be rewarded without testing
It will be judged by human standards
questions.correctAnswer: It will be revealed for its quality
questions.explanation: Paul explains that the fire will test every man's work to show its true nature (1 Corinthians 3:13). This testing aligns with passages like 1 Peter 1:7 and Malachi 3:2-3 about purification by fire.

questions.question: What does Paul say about a man whose work is burned up but who himself is saved?
options: He suffers loss but is saved as through fire
He is condemned with his work
He gains reward despite the loss
He is saved without any loss
questions.correctAnswer: He suffers loss but is saved as through fire
questions.explanation: Paul indicates that if a man's work is burned, he suffers loss but still will be saved, yet so as through fire (1 Corinthians 3:15). This echoes 2 Timothy 2:19 and Zechariah 13:9 where purification involves loss but not loss of salvation.

questions.question: How does Paul describe believers in relation to God in 1 Corinthians 3?
questions.explanation: Paul calls believers God's husbandry and God's building (1 Corinthians 3:9), highlighting their role as cultivated and constructed by God. This is consistent with Ephesians 2:19-22 and Psalm 127:1 which use similar metaphors.

questions.question: What warning does Paul give regarding how each person builds upon the foundation of Christ?
options: Let every man take heed how he buildeth thereupon
Ignore the foundation and build on tradition
Build only with wood and hay
questions.correctAnswer: Let every man take heed how he buildeth thereupon
questions.explanation: Paul exhorts believers to be careful how they build upon the foundation, emphasizing responsibility and accountability (1 Corinthians 3:10). This principle is echoed in Matthew 7:24-27 and Luke 6:47-49.

questions.question: Which materials does Paul mention as possible substances used to build upon the foundation in 1 Corinthians 3?
options: Gold, silver, precious stones, wood, hay, stubble
questions.correctAnswer: Gold, silver, precious stones, wood, hay, stubble
questions.explanation: Paul lists gold, silver, precious stones, wood, hay, and stubble as materials used in building upon the foundation, symbolizing different qualities of works (1 Corinthians 3:12). This imagery is consistent with Zechariah 13:9 and Revelation 21:18-21.

questions.question: What does Paul say about the Corinthians being the temple of God?
options: The Spirit of God dwells in you
The temple is a physical building only
God does not dwell in temples
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit of God dwells in you
questions.explanation: Paul reminds the Corinthians that they are the temple of God and the Spirit of God dwells in them (1 Corinthians 3:16). This teaching is consistent with John 14:17 and 2 Corinthians 6:16 emphasizing the indwelling Spirit.

questions.question: What consequence does Paul state will come upon anyone who defiles the temple of God?
options: He will be forgiven without consequence
questions.explanation: Paul warns that anyone who defiles the temple of God will be destroyed by God because the temple is holy (1 Corinthians 3:17). This is corroborated by Leviticus 10:3 and Psalm 78:60 regarding God's judgment on desecration.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 3, how should one who thinks himself wise in this world behave?
options: Become a fool to become truly wise
questions.correctAnswer: Become a fool to become truly wise
questions.explanation: Paul advises that if anyone seems wise in worldly terms, he should become a fool to be truly wise (1 Corinthians 3:18). This reflects Proverbs 3:5-7 and Matthew 11:25 where God reveals wisdom in humility.

questions.question: What does Paul say about the wisdom of this world in 1 Corinthians 3?
options: It is the highest form of wisdom
It is the foundation of truth
It is equal to godly wisdom
questions.explanation: Paul declares that worldly wisdom is foolishness to God (1 Corinthians 3:19), consistent with Isaiah 29:14 and Jeremiah 9:23-24 which contrast human and divine wisdom.

questions.question: What does Paul say about boasting in men in 1 Corinthians 3?
options: No one should boast in men because all things belong to believers
questions.correctAnswer: No one should boast in men because all things belong to believers
questions.explanation: Paul instructs that no one should boast in humans since all things—Paul, Apollos, Cephas, life, death, present, and future—are believers’ (1 Corinthians 3:21-22). This aligns with Galatians 6:14 and Jeremiah 9:23-24 emphasizing boasting only in the Lord.

questions.question: What ultimate relationship does Paul affirm about believers in 1 Corinthians 3?
options: Believers belong to Christ, and Christ belongs to God
Believers belong to Paul, and Paul belongs to Christ
Believers belong to the world, and the world belongs to God
Believers belong to Apollos, and Apollos belongs to Paul
questions.correctAnswer: Believers belong to Christ, and Christ belongs to God
questions.explanation: Paul concludes that believers are Christ’s, and Christ is God’s (1 Corinthians 3:23), underscoring the divine order and unity. This is echoed in Romans 14:8 and John 10:29 emphasizing belonging and divine authority.
